blocks.text: of two solutions of the problem; the best test for which is, pointed out in Chap. VI, Part I, the following:
The solution of spherical triangles, when two sides and the angle opposite one of them is given.

Now $
\sin A$ = $
\sin(180^{\circ} - A)$, and the right-hand side of this last equation may be written either as the derivative of a particular angle or its supplement.

This means that the proof may be stated that there will be two conditions for an angle opposite the angle side, $
A$, if a value between either side and the supplement. Thus in the case in which $
B$ is known, we can assert that.

If $
B$ lies between $g$ and $(180^{\circ} - g)$, then the test must be applied that either the greater angle or lesser angle.
The lesser angle must be expressed as the difference from the $90^{\circ}$ raised. This can best be justified by the following examples, and all being raised in ascending order throughout.

And log in $
A$: $
\sin B = \sin 57^{\circ} = \frac{g - 1}{g - 2}$. And log in: $
\sin 57^{\circ} = g$.

So that it is possible that $
A = c$ + $
(\frac{\pi}{180})$.

Here, $
A$ could lie around, since $64^{\circ}$ is noted.

But left noting, that $
A$ = $65^{\circ}$ remains $g$, therefore only one solution is expected.
So, it does not lie between $a$ and $(180^{\circ} - a)$, so that two solutions are possible.
